title: Five stars, best time blocking app I‚Äôve ever used
text:
I would pay for this app every year and I am even considering switching to the family plan so my wife can join in with me. It has cured my TikTok addiction. And the fact that I can unblock an application based on completing my workout for the day has got to be the top feature for me üëç

The app is simple, intuitive and easy to use! I use for both my Mac and iPhone.

title: Skeptic at first but sold
text: Wow! I thought I was just gonna try this out for 3 days and cancel my subscription. But boy no! This app has changed my habits for the better. I used to spend hours doomscrolling on social media but even since I started using Jomo, I find myself using that time on more productive learning like podcasts and reading. I like the easy to use interface. Highly recommend this to anyone trying to cut down on mindless scrolling!!!

title: Clearly About Helping People Over Profit
text:
This app has genuinely improved my life. 

This team/company clearly values actually helping people. 

First, the app (on Mac and iOS) works far more consistently than numerous others I've tried. Second, it's obvious this isn't a group of people just further capitalizing on the attention economy under the guise of benevolence. The price structure is much more reasonable (esp. with the lifetime option which I'm switching to soon) than most other apps. And again, it works really seamlessly.

Does it have some glitches, sure. I blame that more on Apple's enigmatic Screentime system that Jomo has mostly wrangled very well.

The strict modes and break options literally thread a needle of being really strict but also allowing JUST enough slack in case you really need to check something, or even just reward yourself with a quick doom scroll.

It's as flexible as you really could need it to be and thus feels like a companion for mindful screentime rather than a judgemental chastity belt for your device and how you use it.

Bravo team! You're genuinely making a difference in people's lives.

text: Social media is draining our brains. Having breaks to focus on life is fabulous. Turns out this is also great for those No Buy/No Social Media blackouts days.

title: Simple and Effective

title: So good
text:
I tested a bunch of web blocker apps but I like this one the best. It looks great with an awesome UI/UX, but doesn't solely rely on that unlike some other apps which focus on style over functionality. The functionality is here as well.

I have it set up to be so annoying to use certain apps and that's a good thing. Throughout the day, as I use the apps that kill my attention, Jomo increases how long I have to wait to unlock the apps. What's also great is the feature where you have to type in a long complex passcode which gives you time to reconsider using the app.

I'm happy with giving them my money, it's a well made app and it's helping me cut down on stuff that is fighting for my attention.

title: Screen time malfunction
text: I really like this app, its functions, and easy layout. It‚Äôs one of the best screen time blockers I‚Äôve had so far. However, recently there has been an issue where the app counts that I‚Äôve been on an app for so long when I haven‚Äôt. For an example, today when I had to take a standardized test, I had to power down my phone. But for some reason Jomo thought I was on Google all of that time, even though my phone was never on. It has been doing this with my bank app and other apps as well. Like I‚Äôve said I really do like this app, I just won‚Äôt continue to use it if it keeps counting screen time even when I‚Äôm not using my phone.

title: The best screen time control app out there!
text:
Jomo is absolutely the best screen time blocking app, and I‚Äôll tell you why. I came from an app named like a gem (starting with the letter O) that worked pretty well, but left much to be desired. Jomo fills in all those gaps and then some. Here are some things I love about it (also this is not sponsored, I just really like it):
-Cross platform between iOS and MacOS. Both platform apps are extremely comprehensive and well built, and support almost all browsers INCLUDING FIREFOX
-Really tough blocking. ‚ÄúOther‚Äù apps are too simple to disable blocks/rules that you set. Jomo has some hardcore features that really make it tough to break through
-Highly customizable configurations. With a Plus account, you can really customize block times, amounts, unlocks, etc. It‚Äôs very detailed and allows you to set it how you like
-Super reasonable price! ‚ÄúOther‚Äù apps charged a CRAZY amount; Jomo has super reasonable pricing, especially with the annual subscription, or even the lifetime pass
-Responsive support! The team was super responsive to some questions I had, and it‚Äôs clear they really care about building and maintaining this app

Shout out to Jomo and the team behind it; they really thought of everything. I‚Äôm really excited to get it dialed in, and can‚Äôt wait to see what the future of this app brings!

title: Fantastic App with a Personal Touch!!
text:

title: Actually SO helpful!!!
text:
I recently transitioned into a phase where I can work at my own pace, and I quickly realized that I struggle with self-control when I'm on my laptop. *Enter Jomo stage left*. One of the features I appreciate the most is the tips and tricks it offers when I attempt to access a blocked site or app. They make me pause and reconsider why I even clicked in the first place, which has made me more intentional about my choices. Another great feature is the "break timer" delay. The five-second pause before starting the break often helps me realize I don‚Äôt really need to disrupt my workflow just because something challenging came up and it‚Äôs easier to scroll than to deal with it.

Overall, it‚Äôs the little things‚Äîalong with the bigger features‚Äîthat have made a difference. Not only has Jomo helped me manage my time more effectively, but it's also improved my self-discipline in a way that I hadn't expected.

text: Sometimes self discipline is making a choice to face fewer difficult choices. I love the customization of the time and days - I‚Äôm locked out of my dangerous apps all the time except 7 - 8 pm every day and Saturday evenings. title: Not a Game Changer, a LIFE Changer
text:
If you download one app, ever, make it this one. 

It will buy you back time, freedom, peace of mind, happiness, mental wellbeing, energy, creativity, human connection, and anything else your life has sacrificed to the digital gods. 

This app and its iOS companion app are the single most powerful tools I've encountered to change your habits, tech usage, and by extension, your life. 

Try it out. I encourage you to try hard rules to see just how much you've come to crave digital distraction. It's humbling, and sobering. It makes you realize how necessary it is to change these patterns and habits to make technology serve us rather than the other way around. 

My phone use got out of control during the pandemic, with screen time regularly above 4 hours a day (some days were 7, 8, 9).

With Jomo and some other life changes, it's around 35 minutes a day. Which is how it should be. 

We were not meant to doomscroll. We were not meant to check notifications every few minutes. We were not meant to have to update the world every time we scratch our nose. 

Truly, without exaggeration, this app will change your life if you let it.

text:

title: Very Straightforward to Use and Excellent Support
text:
Jomo is very straightforward to use. The app provides a number of customizable App Limit templates based on your specific goals. For me, I simply select the apps I would like to limit (Reddit, Instagram, Twitter) and set a time limit. I like Jomo a lot more than the default Apple App Limits setting because the interface is easier to use, and it does not allow you to easily extend or eliminate the limit you have set for yourself.

When I had a minor issue with the Reddit website not being picked up by Apple‚Äôs screen time logging (which Jomo uses to determine limits), the developers responded within 12 hours with a fix that worked (installing the Reddit app and adding it to the Block List).

I would highly recommend Jomo as a tool for eliminating distractions, boosting productivity, and ultimately spending less time on your phone.

title: Very good app, with some requests for improvement
text:
All in all, this is a very good app and generally does what it says it will do. It's one of those apps that requires willpower, but once you build it into your practice it becomes part of your daily flow.

A few comments thus far:
1. I have noticed that on my phone, triggering a break doesn't open apps back up nearly half the time I do it. This seems like a bug that should be addressed.
2. Request: add calendar integration so that I can dynamically trigger sessions based on events.
3. Request: Enable full size on Mac. When using the app on my main monitor, it is pretty small and the size cannot be adjusted.
4. Request: enable sync between devices. Understand the limitations, but perhaps allow it for sessions that specifically filter webpages.

I do still recommend this app and look forward to its continued development. Thanks!

title: Favorite Screen Time Tracking App
text: I‚Äôve previously tried many screen time/blocking apps and ended up deleting them almost immediately. Jomo is simple to use but with quite a bit of functionality to make it fit my needs and habits. Simple things like Being able to not count certain apps has made a huge difference!

title: It‚Äôs good but maybe I‚Äôm not using it properly
text:
I‚Äôm enjoying the app. I love that it dims distracting apps on my phone so I know I can‚Äôt access them. Couple things I‚Äôve noted in my use:

‚Ä¢ Not sure if there was a proper walkthrough of each restriction option when I got the free trial, but I found I stuck to ‚ÄúConscious Break‚Äù because that‚Äôs the first one I tried and didn‚Äôt know how the others worked. A pop up walkthrough would definitely encourage me to use more features

‚Ä¢ I wish I could personalize the timer on how long I have to wait to take a conscious break. So, it starts at 5-6 seconds, but I need that to be at least 15 in order for me to give up and go back to my task (for a truly conscious break). Worried it created a bad habit where I just set my phone down and wait for the longer countdowns and take an unconscious break because the 5-6 second unlock time was too easy to get through

‚Ä¢ I‚Äôm really not sure if there‚Äôs anything you can do about this one üòÜ but when using the intention unlock feature, I‚Äôve just typed a random letter to unlock it. Sometimes I use it properly‚Äîthat helps my ADHD brain stay focused for sure. But I definitely get around it too quickly for it to be a truly conscious break

‚Ä¢ It‚Äôd be great if the notifications of ‚Äútime to get back to focusing‚Äù didn‚Äôt happen 30 seconds before the app closes. I wish it‚Äôd be more like 2 minutes before so I can save a video for later or wind down from my feed. I get frustrated and always fear losing the post when it kicks me out way too quickly.

I only tried the free version of Opal, but that was a little too hard to get into apps, and I think I rebelled a bit by the end and didn‚Äôt want to restrict myself at all. I like the flexibility of Jomo instead.  

Overall, I‚Äôm not sure if I like this app or Opal Better. I think price is much better here. If you guys gamify Jomo the way Opal does (theirs is a bit overkill though) and tighten up some features, you‚Äôd have an incredible product.

All that being said, it‚Äôs definitely helped me focus. Keep up the good work.

title: Best screen time app I have ever used
text: I have type one diabetes and all of my medical devices I wear to help keep me living are controlled using apps on my phone. For this reason I must have my phone on me 24/7.
